prompt: Write a poem about name badge in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Badge-Wars

'Twas brillig, and the slithy badges
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe;
All mimsy were the nameplate scratches,
And the frumious clip clip-crabbed in the cubicle-wall.

"Beware the Title-Snatcher, my son!
The frabjous pins that catch!
Beware the Office Ghoul, and shun
The mimsy Wobblyatch!"

He took his vorpal lanyard in hand;
Long time the name-badge sought he—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in office-thought he stood,
The Title-Snatcher, with eyes of hate,
Came whiffling through the tulgey hall,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal lanyard went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its thread
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Title-Snatcher?
Come to my chest, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on bittersweet victory in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Blightenheel's Fall

'Twas brillig, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe;
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the mome raths outgrabe.

"Beware the Blightenheel, my son!
The claws that scratch, the teeth that gnash!
Beware the ugsome Wooble-wrum,
And shun the Grumble-nash!"

He took his vorpal sword in hand:
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Blightenheel, with eyes of bile,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Blightenheel?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

But when he held the glistening head,
The sweetness turned to burning blight:
For in the eyes, both dread and dead,
He saw the fading light.

The victory was thrummed and drear,
The joy was mixed with sorrow's tear:
To win the fight, he'd faced his fear,
But lost the thing he held so dear.

The blade was bright, the battle done,
But pleasure mingled with the pain:
For every victory 'neath the sun
Loses something in the gain.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about a promise kept in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Promise's Path

I swore an oath upon a Glittertree,
To keep my faith through all I see,
Through mimsy woods and borogove lands,
With promise firm in my two hands.

The slithy doubts would mock and jeer,
But steadfast purpose brought me near,
The uffish foes that tried to sway,
My promise I would keep and pray.

He took his words in his right hand,
Long time the manxome doubts he sought—
Through tulgy woods and borogove land,
Forgetting not the promise he was taught.

And, as in hopeful thought he stood,
The Worrisnatches came whiffling by,
Bubbling with doubt as robins fly,
With tears in their vorpal eye.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
His promise kept throughout the day!
The doubts fell dead, with words instead,
His oath had proved it more than pay.

And hast thou kept thy solemn vow?
"Yes, indeed, I've kept it now!"
And hast thou conquered all the fears?
Come to my arms, my beamish peer!

O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
He chortled in his joyous way!
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about paperclip chain in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
"The Clipper's Frabjous Chain"

"'Twas brillig, and the slithy clips
Did gyre and gimble on the tray:
All mimsy were the silver chains,
And the borogoves did outgrabe.

"Beware the Binder's hungry jaws,
The teeth that bite, the clips that catch!
Beware the tangled Demon, and shun
The frumious mess!

"He took his Vorpal Paperclip in hand:
Long time the manxome chains he sought—
So rested he by the memo stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

"And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Clip-chain, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the cluttered wood,
And burbled as it came!

"One, two! One, two! And clip by clip
The vorpal chain went snicker-snack!
He bent them tight, with joyful might,
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou wrought the Clip-chain grand?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy."
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on control theory in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Loop-Tamer

'Twas brillig, and the slithy systems
Did gyre and gimble in the phase;
All mimsy were the response curves,
And the compensators outgrabe.

"Beware the gain, my son!
The phase that bites, the margin thin!
Beware the poles, and shun
The zeros within!"

He took his controller board in hand;
Long time the parameters he sought—
So rested he by the frequency sand
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in loop-shaping thought he stood,
The unstable system, with eyes of lead,
Came whiffling through the transient wood,
And burbled as it came—he heeded!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The tuned compensator went snicker-snack!
He left it stable, with phase margin
He went galumphing back with Bode in pack!

"And hast thou slain the instability?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy!

'Twas brillig, and the slithy systems
Did gyre and gimble in the phase;
All mimsy were the response curves,
And the compensators outgrabe.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about error correction in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Errortamer

'Twas compiling and the data stream
Did scramble in the system core:
All checksummed were the memory bytes,
And the errors no more.

"Beware the segmentation fault, my son!
The race conditions that arise!
Beware the nullpointer's run,
The deadlock's dying cries!"

He took his terminal in hand;
Long time the memory leak he sought—
So rested he by the guardian code-tree,
And stood in debugging thought.

And, as in validation-thought he stood,
The segfault with eyes of dread,
Came flickering through the ethernet grove,
And burbled as it spread!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The memory leak he patched clean through;
He sealed it tight, with garbage reclaim
He went triumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the segfault?
Come to my arms, my debugging boy!
O algorithm day! Optimization! Correction!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas compiling and the data stream
Did flow in perfect alignment through the core:
All checksummed were the memory bytes,
And the errors no more.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about evening breeze in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Breezeway

Twas evening dim, and slithy shadows creep
While zephyrs wake the sleepy world and stept;
All fragrant were the borogoves with glee,
As evening breezes sweep the landscape free.

Beware the Chilf, my child!
The nip that bites, the frost that bites!
Beware the Misting, shun the bright
The prismatic hues that fade to night!

The sun took leave with glistening, goldy light,
Long did it fade beyond the mountains height—
So rested 'neath the blooming Tint sky blue,
And watched the clouds in Umber-hues grew.

And, as in twilight colors it did sink,
The Zephyrus with whispers soft and pink
Came rustling through the violet-hazed trees
And burbled leaves in symphony.

Whish, whish! Whish, whish! Through every tree,
The Zephyrus sang wild and free!
It touched the flowers, kissed the streams,
And woke the world from daylight's dreams.

And hast thou brought the coolness, soft and mild?
Come to my arms, my glee child!
O fragrant night! Wondrous embrace!
The nature world breathed out in grace.

Twas evening dim, and slithy shadows creep
While zephyrs wake the sleepy world and stept;
All fragrant were the borogoves with glee,
As evening breezes sweep the landscape free.
label: low

prompt: Compose a poem on zebra crossing in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Zebrawalk

'Twas streetclear on the urban scene,
Where bipeds bustled swift and keen;
The traffic snarled with grumble-bites,
As crosswalk stripes brought guiding lights.

Beware the Rushmobiles, my son!
The speeding beasts that cut and run!
Take the Zebra-path with care;
Just stand and wait beyond compare.

The Whizzers came with angry squeals,
With rumbling tires and spinning wheels;
They swerved and shot through snarled-up rows,
While traffic lights went "GO-SLOW!"

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The striated path he trod!
He left them gleaming, safe-streaming,
He walked across with one big nod.

"And hast thou faced the Rushmobiles?
Come tell your tale, my careful boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
You navigated life's alloy!"

'Twas streetclear, and the walking folk
Did pace and prance along the street;
All mimsy were the zebrapaths,
And the safe crossings felt complete!
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about moving day in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
# The Movescapade

The box-stack grew, the bubble-wrap did spread,
The Movertwits came with thumping tread.
The Tote-em-up, the Carrying-crew,
Lifted all that we held new.

Beware the Fragiletotes, my boy!
The things that break bring阵阵 joy!
Beware the Floorstrewn-tacks that jump,
And catch your slip with sudden thump!

He took his Vorpal packing tape,
To seal the boxes at a great rate.
The Bump-wiggle slid near his feet,
He'd box the chairs, he'd pack the seat.

He lumbered through his dusty hall,
The Shove-pack groaned, began to fall.
One two! One two! Through and through,
The truck swallowed all the view!

He chortled in his packing glee,
"The movescapade was meant for me!"
And hast thou fought the Move-day throng?
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about burnt toast in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Munchy-toast

'Twas crisp-i-fry, and the kitchen-steam
Did bubble and sizzle in the morning light;
All smoky was the breakfast-dream,
And the air quite freight.

"Beware the Char-bit, my son!
The smoke that rises, the toast that burns!
Beware the Toastler-gray,
And shun the frumious Grumble!"

He took his butter-knife in hand;
Long time the perfect-bread he sought—
So rested he by the toaster-land
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in hungriest thought he stood,
The Burnt-toast, with eyes of coal-black,
Came crackling through the toaster-cloud,
And crickled as it cracked!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The butter-knife went the Burnt-toast;
He stabbed it and labored in his haste;

"And hast thou conquered the Burnt-toast?
Come to my plate, my hungry boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He breakfasted with joy.
label: medium
